I grew up in Canada and went to engineering school late 60s to early 70s. All the courses were in Imperial units, which included such arcane and abstruse units as kips (thousand pounds), poundals (force required to give a mass of one pound an acceleration of one foot per second per second) and the slug (the mass that is accelerated by 1 ft/s2 when force of one pound is exerted on it, equal to 32.174 pounds in a 1g gravitational field). I then spent my career working in the SI and quasi SI systems of kPa, bar, and decanewtons, the latter very handy because one dN is roughly equivalent to a mass of 1 kg. Then I went to work in the US and went back to the Imperial system. Crazy

Most of the world converted to metric because it solved a significant problem that didn't exist in the US. In the UK and Europe, there were thousands of different units of measure. Milk had its own unit of measure, wine had a different unit of measure, and essentially every liquid commodity had its own unit of measure. Then, barley had its own unit if measured, wheat had a different unit of measure, corn had a different unit of measure, and so on. Same issue with length. Further, there was no reasonable conversion from one unit of measure to another. Metric solved this problem with one unit of measure (with multiples and fractions) for volume, mass, and length -- liter, gram, and meter.
If you ask someone in the UK how big a gallon is, they'll need you the specific which gallon measure. That was never a problem is the US. We have gallons for volume, feet for length, and pounds for weight (with multiples and fraction). And that's for anything you want to measure -- apple juice, gasoline, olive oil, lard, milk, barley, sand, concrete, rice, honey, fabric, rope, chain, etc.
Yes, the US does have a wet gallon and a dry gallon, but have fun even finding anyone who knows the different. We just use one unit a measure (with fractions and multiples).

I don't understand how you can say that the imperial units are "Defined" by metric units. How are you "defining" anything by merely pointing out an equivalency? Saying 0.3048 meters equals 1 foot is no different to saying 12 inches equals 1 foot. Both are equally as arbitrary at describing the phenomenon known as length. Neither of them define it. "Ok, so how long is a meter then? How long is an inch? What's a foot?" So to use one as a "Definition" to the other is pointless since they're all reversible. I could just as easily "Define" the entire Metric system in Imperial Units.

A true definition would be where that arbitrary unit of length originated from and was agreed to be the length that it is. If its agreed that a meter is 1 10-millionth of the distance between the north pole and the equator passing through Paris, then that's it's definition. It's the exact same story for every other standardized unit of measure in existence.

We're smart enough to be metric when it suits us. "Metric" doesn't mean "meters" or "grams." It means BASE TEN, and that's all it means.

Here's what you need to know about scientific measurements in short. Common measures will be in parenthesis. If you're struggling with them, it'll do good for you to read them out loud.
Units used in examples are length (m, meter), mass (g and t, gram and ton), volume (l, liter) and pressure (Pa, Pascals). Here goes:

m - mili - divide by 1000 (mm, mg, ml)
c - centi - divide by 100 (cm).
d - deci - divide by 10 (dm, dl)
base unit
da - deca - multiply by 10 (dag)
h - hecto - multiply by 100 (hPa)
k - kilo - multiply by 1000 (km, kg, kt).
M - mega - multiply by million (Mt, MB).

Smaller than m- are used in microscopic scales and smaller. Larger than M- are common in computer science data measurement. Every next larger unit further multiplies by 1000 (divides for smaller).


Trivia:
- Notice that there's 100 cents in a dollar because it's jargon for "one hundredth piece". Same with % - "per cent"
- USA military calls km "clicks".
- Units derived from scientist names (Pa for Pascal, T for Tesla, V for Volt,...) are written with a capital letter out of respect.
- k- and smaller is lowercase. M- and larger are in caps.
- Anything byte-related actually multiplies with 1024 instead of 1000. kB, MB, GB, TB.

I invite everyone staying in Paris to take a ride in the beautiful garden surounding the storage bunker of the prototype-kilogram, in the parisian suburb of Sèvres ("say-vre"). This park, named Parc de Saint-Cloud ("sain-kloo"), is one of the cutest exemples of XVIth century countryside-like gardens, with their typical "à la française" designs (geometric shapes, showing "the dominance of Man upon nature"). It used to be the home of "Monsieur", brother of King Louis XIV, and is now a public park with lots to see and enjoy.
The BIPM (Bureau International des Poids et Mesures = International Bureau of Measures and Weights) ; the nearby Manufacture royale de Sèvres (a school and "living museum" for the finest in arts and craft of ceramics, producing to bestest of them) ; the sports club Le Stade français (founded 1883, featuring 22 different sports from track-and-field to rugby or rowing) ; several gastronomic restaurants ; "La Grande Cascade" (a huge garden waterfall, legacy from the royal era) ; the annual "Le Grand feu" (largest fireworks event in Europe, as a tribute to those set up by the "Sun King" Louis XIV), etc. etc.
The Parc de Saint-Cloud is a must-see for anyone enjoying the nicest places. The integral of the metric system is decimal. Therefore, the conversion of kilogram-gram, kilometer-millimeter is determined only by the decimal coefficient between units, but there is no change in the notation value resulting from the displacement of each unit.
In other words, 1-meter and 50-centimeter can be written in just 150 centimeters.
The preceding numbers 1 and 5 remain unchanged.
This remains the same even when combined with other measures, eg mass.
If there is a 45g iron bar at 1m, it will be written as 45g/m.
If this is changed in cm, the expression value [45] in 0.45 g/cm is unchanged.
But what about 5'8" in the pound-yard method?
5 feet 8 inches would be 5+8/12=5.6666666666....feet if unified towards the feet,
If unified in inches, it would be (5x12)+8=68 inches.
Either way, the value that was written on a daily basis is losing its meaning.
So what happens when you combine this with the weight?
It is impossible to predict a bit. Somehow, there will be a huge number of false expressions. Perhaps multiple units are needed.
Yards and feet, inches, and pounds and ounces.
The core of the metric system is decimal. This is different from the unit system we use intuitively. However, by using a decimal number that can be converted at any equator, we can grasp and apply many concepts that will disappear due to differences of opinion.

In the US we are free to use whatever system we like.  The US government has never made it a law, unlike most other countries. That's a fundamental difference.  NASA uses the metric system because it's easier and it's less likely for humans to make mistakes with it. I use inches and feet.

I was working on a sterile filling machine from Bosch in Cralscheim (their pharmaceutical packaging, manufacturing plant), which is in Ireland. I got asked to go help with the replacement of parts of a similar machine made in the US which was to be converted to fill the same syringes they fill here Ireland. Everything was in fractions of inches. I didn't say anything, it's not the first time I've used Imperial on high tolerance parts. However, this was the first time I hadn't been requested to send any parts designed, back in Imperial, and a couple of small parts were drawn up in both Imperial and metric already. As the team I was working with were all Irish or German, we agreed to work in metric. A few weeks later, parts are written up, the requested ones made, and the remaining drawings emailed over to the US. Within a few hours, we got a call asking if what we had sent was a joke. Why wed sent everything in metric, to America. Some harsh words were sent on the phone, and some unessicery claims made. A few days later and after some more aggressive calls, and a very quick meeting to investigate for clarification from our side back home in Ireland, we were told we would need to pay up for the costs involved for sending it all in metric. To which we replied, we're sorry such a large problem had occurred, the parts had been fitted, tested, and were well within the requested tolerances. We then decided to reference the treaty of the metre and that metric was part of the ISO, and hoped the yanks wouldn't start paying for solicitor work, which would be useless, and a waist of their money. The very next day, we were told they'd stopped complaining.
My experience with US companies in Ireland has typically been very positive outside of how they treat their employees. They make it very clear what they do and don't want in what system. Metric is the standard, they know that's what we use. This time just seemed to be a really bad example....

The important thing is not the absolute amount of each unit
Correlation between units.
Integers in the metric system do not consist of base quantities, but the relationship of each unit consists of all the arithmetic numbers we use and the base of mathematics.
Because of this, moving between units is easily done by adding or subtracting zeros to the last digit, rather than complex calculations, and it plays an important role in eliminating digits in the calculations and intuitively helping to understand important indicators.

In this sense, the United States also claims to use the metric system because the basic quantity of all US troops is fixed to the absolute value of the metric system. It is pointless in metric terms.

The US length measurement is relative to the meter, however. It was defined by the Swedish inventor: Carl Edvard Johansson. The US and British "yard" had become two separate lengths. As I understand it, and unbeknownst to both countries, Johansson had already solved their problem before they realized it was one (around WWI?.) He had simply split the difference, and so an inch is 'exactly' 25.4 mm. Anything made calibrated using his gauge blocks was already correct.

Later on, the governments made it official.

When the measurements are so precise they have to account for air density you have to wonder how they deal with gravitational differences on earth.... After all the gravitational force is not constant on earth because it is not perfectly spherical, nor uniform in composition. There will be more gravity towards the equator where the earth is "fatter". Also, there will be the centrifugal force counteracting gravity, and that will be greater towards the equator. Even the altitude of where you measure at is going to have some impact since gravity works by proximity to the mass - so WHERE you decide to measure it is inevitably going to affect the result (a tiny amount).

These factors rarely come into play because they are trivial in size for most practical applications, but it would be interresting to know how (and to what degree) they deal with them in striving to be perfectly accurate...

How do they calibrate the mass comparator? There is some device which generates signal X from the standard kilogram and a signal Y from the unit under test. But to be able to say that signal Y represents a mass of Z kilograms there must be some sort of calibration done to that mass comparator. If there are 10 "standard" masses say ranging from 0.999KG to 1.001KG then those masses can establish a calibration curve for the mass comparator; and measured masses are interpolations between the "standard" points. With a single point standard like the kilogram, one must rely on the 0 mass point to create the curve, but how do we know that the behaviour of this mass comparator is linear from 0 to beyond 1KG and beyond?

Many Americans who aren't scientists or engineers are not aware that the metric standard is used nearly everywhere in American technology.  It's true that the imperial standard is often still used in engineering, but is secondary to the metric in many applications, even sometimes mixed.  Most competent American engineers are very familiar with both systems, and easily convert measurements between them with fidelity to tight tolerances.  The trend toward thorough conversion to the metric system is slow because of America's massive industry that includes stock material sizes, component sizes and legacy tooling that's an incredibly large national investment that cannot be abandoned rapidly without important economic consequences.

This is infinitely more useful in everyday life, just not for science. So having both systems allowed both educated and non-educated people to measure things how their lives required.

That is how FREEDOM works, you are FREE to use whatever tools make your life easier, rather than being required by law to adhere to some arbitrary scientific standard invented by the French. Spoiler (from Wikipedia):

In October 2010, the CIPM voted to submit a resolution for consideration at the General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM), to "take note of an intention" that the kilogram be defined in terms of the Planck constant, h (which has dimensions of energy times time) together with other fundamental units. This resolution was accepted by the 24th conference of the CGPM in October 2011 and further discussed at the 25th conference in 2014. Although the Committee recognized that significant progress had been made, they concluded that the data did not appear sufficiently robust to adopt the revised definition and that work should continue to enable the adoption at the 26th meeting, scheduled for 2018. Such a definition would theoretically permit any apparatus that was capable of delineating the kilogram in terms of the Planck constant to be used as long as it possessed sufficient precision, accuracy, and stability.

As a Filipino American, I understand the worlds distaste of the Imperial system, and I understand the few imperial countries have a hard time working to go with the popular SI units. I use Imperial measurements because I am a Fathom tall (one fathom is 6 ft), which means the distance of my center to my out stretched arm is a yard. My middle finger is 4 inches long, 1/2" wide, and my whole hand is 8 inches long. I can give someone a probable estimate of anything just by using my body as a reference. This is useful in my line of engineering where I can measure something with relative accuracy just with my hand or arm.

Yet I'm a man of science and I'm so used to calculating buoyancy with newtons, cubic centimeters, and milliliters. Its so easy since the SI units interchange so easily. I feel that metric and the general SI unit system is universally used in science, yet the imperial system maintains its strong hold in architecture and other engineering fields. I could learn my height using meters/cm, but it doesn't hit even for me, its not a solid 6ft, 3ft, 4in, 8in, or half inch.

Since 1 liter of water weighs 1 kg, (and other conversions that it's supposed to simplify) it DOES matter if the kilogram changes.

The new definition will use m = hv/(c^2) where
h = planks constant
v = the frequency of a photon (units of 1/s)
c = speed of light

All of these are fundamental units and already well defined. In 2018, the most refined estimate of 'h' will be created from independent experiments around world and with it the kg re-defined.

Youtube search "Redefining the Kilogram with the DIY Watt Balance" for an awesome video by Practical Engineering on this.

You didn't talk about units for measuring length, here, but I have a story about that. You see, I'm 39, now, and back in fifth grade, they taught us the metric system at the school I was going to. That school ended up closing, soon thereafter, and I don't know why, but a few years later, I was traveling with my aunt, uncle, and two cousins, to a different state, to see another cousin get married. We were traveling by car, and at every rest stop, someone would raise the question, "Have we traveled 1000 miles, yet?"

My younger cousin, after I said something about this question (I don't remember what), said, "But for sure, the van has traveled more than 1000 millimeters?"

Now, it had been several years since I had given metric units for measuring distance any thought, but before I could give this suggestion any consideration, my older cousin jumped in and said, "Well of course it has traveled more than 1000 millimeters! It covered 1000 millimeters in the first block!"

To be fair, that's true. It had covered 1000 millimeters in the first block. But as I thought on the unit and dug up what I had learned, years earlier, the humor in the suggestion and the counter-suggestion became apparent to me.

The prefix "milli" in "millimeter" means "thousandth." 1000 millimeters is 1000 thousandths of a meter or 1 meter. A meter is just a few inches more than a yard. So when you say, "This van has covered 1000 millimeters," you are saying, "This van has covered a meter," or "This van has covered a yard and three inches." The van covered 1000 millimeters, more than three times, just sitting there. It probably traveled 1000 millimeters, three or four times before it was all the way out of the driveway.

But each of those changes would change the measured mass of everything else in the universe.

The problem with metric is there is no parlance for the foot and inch equivalent. Do I think fractions are stupid? Of course. I'm fine with a 10 base system. But outside a lab, we can easily visualize inches, feet and yards. (An inch is about a knuckle, a foot is obvious, and a yard is about a grown man's stride)

The meter being broken down into such tiny units beyond 100 centimeters and 1,000 millimeters is just a silly way for the average guy to approximate a distance. We are visual creatures, and can use our hands to describe widths and thicknesses. When we hold two hands out in front of our chest, palms facing in, we can approximate what a foot is. When we hold a gap between our fingers we can approximate what an inch is. If I had to describe what a foot was, in a visual way, with metric as the new standard, I could hold out my hands and approximate a gap width of 3 Decimeters.

The metric system would take off if it was common to use the Decimeter (dm). The usage of the word actually shows up in the Senate's Executive Documents of 1890, and how to use it. A Decimeter is about 4 inches. Half a decimeter is 2 inches. So if you said something was two and a half Decimeters it would be about 10 inches. Three Decimeters brings us back to our favorite, the foot, or close to 12 inches. Those are things we can visualize and relate to. Bring Decimeter back into casual measurements, and metric system will gradually win over the last of the holdouts.

Wikipedia:

In October 2010, the CIPM voted to submit a resolution for consideration at the General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM), to "take note of an intention" that the kilogram be defined in terms of the Planck constant, h (which has dimensions of energy times time) together with other fundamental units.[59][60] This resolution was accepted by the 24th conference of the CGPM[61] in October 2011 and further discussed at the 25th conference in 2014.[62][63] Although the Committee recognised that significant progress had been made, they concluded that the data did not appear sufficiently robust to adopt the revised definition, and that work should continue to enable the adoption at the 26th meeting, scheduled for 2018.[62] Such a definition would theoretically permit any apparatus that was capable of delineating the kilogram in terms of the Planck constant to be used as long as it possessed sufficient precision, accuracy and stability.
